Bone-Forming and Cartilage-Forming Neopl.text: Conventional OS is composed of pleomorphic cells demonstrating production of extracellular osteoid matrix
Pleomorphic cells are most easily located in areas away from prominent osteoid formation
Neoplastic osteoid tends to form âstreamersâ or a lacy pattern that appears disorganized with few intervening stromal tissues
The osteoid lacks osteoblastic rimming, which is characteristic of maturing fracture callus
Some OS may show chondrosarcomatous or fibrosarcomatous differentiation
Confluent lobules of cartilaginous matrix that are hypercellular and have a disordered appearance and uneven distribution
Varying degrees of atypia and pleomorphism can be present and used for tumor grading
Osteoid production by neoplastic cells should not be seen
Invasion of the marrow with trapping of host lamellar bone helps distinguish CS from benign lesions and fracture
Orderly arrangement and gradual transition from one matrix type to another are not seen in CS

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: On occasion, an early or incipient fracture can mimic a sarcoma both clinically and pathologically
Benign and malignant lesions can lead to pathologic fracture, and the presence of fracture callus can make interpretation of the fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) or tissue biopsy difficult
To avoid false-positive diagnoses, it is important to be familiar with the pathology of fracture callus
Careful consideration of clinical history and imaging studies are essential parts of the pathologic evaluation

General Pathologic Considerations.text: Distinction is easily made optically if full wave plate, or compensator, is introduced into system between crossed polarizers, usually below substage condenser of microscopeCompensator is transparent crystalline disc made of calcite or selenite quartzLike urate and pyrophosphate crystals, compensator is also birefringent crystal, but wavelengths of ~ 550 nm go through compensator unrotated, so that analyzer (upper polarizer) blocks those wavelengths from passingNet effect is that background, which is dark in polarized light, appears magenta and that any crystals in field are colored blue or yellow on magenta background instead of being white on black background

Terminology.text: Osteoarthrosis is loss of articular cartilage with reconstructive and degenerative changes in articular surface and subarticular bone leading to chronic pain, joint stiffness, and progressive loss of range in joint motion

Clinical Issues.text: Any joint may be affected, but large diarthrodial joints of limbs, facet joints of spine, and distal joints of fingers are particularly susceptible
Process is associated with preexisting factors, such as previous trauma, inflammatory joint diseases, congenital-inherited conditions, and sometimes with metabolic conditions
Treatment is directed toward amelioration of symptoms, but bone changes are not as yet naturally reversible

Imaging.text: Most specific imaging findings are joint narrowing and osteophyte formation

Complementary imaging studies, such as CT and MR, are seldom performed but can sometimes help distinguish between osteoarthrosis and other conditions, which may have crossover symptoms and imaging findings

Macroscopic.text: 3 most important findings: Erosion of articular cartilage, deformities, and osteophyte formation

Microscopic.text: Associated changes include fibrillation and fissuring of articular cartilage through complete loss of cartilage with polishing of subarticular bone and osteophyte formation.

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Superficial subarticular insufficiency fractures, avascular necrosis, inflammatory arthritis

Definitions.text: Loss of articular cartilage with reconstructive and degenerative changes in articular surface and subarticular bone leading to chronic pain, joint stiffness, and progressive loss of range in joint motion

ETIOLOGY/PATHOGENESIS.text: Articular hyaline cartilage is composite tissue that is remnant of ends of embryologic cartilage model of long bonesIts structure and function depends upon integrity of interrelationships between its composite parts, consisting of proteoglycans produced by and replenished by its chondrocytes and type II collagen molecules holding these in placeWhile not part of its structural composite, it has very significant aqueous content because of its hydrophiliaExact amount of water present varies depending upon degree of its deformation
sub_points: Its structure and function depends upon integrity of interrelationships between its composite parts, consisting of proteoglycans produced by and replenished by its chondrocytes and type II collagen molecules holding these in place
While not part of its structural composite, it has very significant aqueous content because of its hydrophilia
Exact amount of water present varies depending upon degree of its deformation

ETIOLOGY/PATHOGENESIS.text: Because hyaline cartilage is avascular, it relies upon diffusion for nourishment and oxygenation, and in its baseline state, and there is no ingress or egress of cellular elements

Maintenance of structural components of cartilage and its physiology depends entirely upon its chondrocytesWhen there is cartilage damage, there is usually compensatory proliferation of chondrocytesIn addition, chondrocytes produce more proteoglycans when there is cartilage damage
sub_points: When there is cartilage damage, there is usually compensatory proliferation of chondrocytes
In addition, chondrocytes produce more proteoglycans when there is cartilage damage

ETIOLOGY/PATHOGENESIS.text: Because of its limited capacity for repair, damage to cartilage tends to be cumulative and irreversibleChondrocytes may replenish themselves and secrete increased quantities of aggrecans, but they do not regenerate structural damage to collagen
sub_points: Chondrocytes may replenish themselves and secrete increased quantities of aggrecans, but they do not regenerate structural damage to collagen

ETIOLOGY/PATHOGENESIS.text: Consequently, anatomic and physiologic derangements to articular cartilage are additive so that degenerative changes progress over time

Presentation.text: Patients usually present with gradual onset of symptoms, including progressive joint stiffness, local pain, and slowly decreasing range of motion
Although any joint may be involved, large joints of lower extremities and of shoulders as well as vertebral facet joints are particularly susceptible
While more than one joint may be affected, it is usual for presentation to be in single joint or for there to be asymmetric progression in several joints
While pain is usually in involved joint, referred pain is also sometimes characteristic
Occasionally, process tends to involve many of distal or proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, or metatarsophalangeal joints

Treatment.text: Conservative measures include oral NSAIDs, local steroid injections, and physical therapy with walking aids
If pain is intolerable or if range of motion is severely limited, then articular surfaces are replaced with joint arthroplasties
If process is associated with systemic immune/inflammatory diseases of synovium, treatment of inflammatory process may ameliorate or delay onset of secondary degenerative changes

Prognosis.text: Slowly progressive process
Degenerative changes are not naturally reversed because articular cartilage is avascular and cannot reconstitute itself
Pain and limitation of motion eventuate in progressive loss of joint function and can progress to point where joint is functionally or anatomically fused

At some point in time, joint arthroplasty to replace joint can be performedLargely successful with large joints of hip, knee, and shoulder, but has been less so in ankle, elbow, and small joints of hands and feet
sub_points: Largely successful with large joints of hip, knee, and shoulder, but has been less so in ankle, elbow, and small joints of hands and feet

General Features.text: Osteoarthrosis is usually evaluated by conventional radiographs
Most specific findings are narrowing of joint space and osteophyte formation

As disease progression continues, subarticular degenerative cysts and pseudocysts may become visible on radiographs, and as cartilage is progressively lost, there are often areas of subchondral osteosclerosis secondary to bone remodeling that accompanies cartilage loss
CT and MR are not regularly performed in patients with DJD
CT may help to better visualize certain joints that are not well evaluated on conventional radiographs (e.g., spinal facet joints and TMJ)

MR is very good for evaluating state of articular cartilage, menisci, ligaments, and other soft tissue structuresSince MR relies on subatomic events for image generation, events that are reversible and not necessarily anatomic may be overinterpretedThis is particularly true when attempting to evaluate degree of cartilage loss by MR alone
sub_points: Since MR relies on subatomic events for image generation, events that are reversible and not necessarily anatomic may be overinterpreted

General Features.text: Hallmark of most gross specimens of large joints is slight to moderate deformation of normal anatomic structure with loss of portions of articular cartilage

In femoral head, humeral head, and femoral condyles, this manifests as visible flattening of convex joint surfaces, while in tibial plateau, there is often accentuated flattening or even concave deformity of articular surface
Cartilage loss may be segmental and focal and it may be fairly diffuse
As cartilage is lost, there is often some degree of subarticular osseous reconstruction resulting in varying degrees of osteosclerosis
Full-thickness loss of cartilage results in apposition of bone on bone in joint, and repeated abrasion of bone on bone causes polishing of opposing osseous surfaces, or eburnation
In joints having greater range of motion and different types of motion (such as knee), smooth polishing may also show linear ridging
Accompanying subarticular bone plate beneath completely eroded surfaces is almost invariably densely sclerotic
Findings are usually most accentuated in weight-bearing areas of joints, so in femoral head they tend to be superior or superolateral; however, they may occur in almost any locus
In hip joint in particular, there may be peripheral deformities or erosion due to femoroacetabular impingement at circumferential margins of femoral head
In multicompartment joints such as knee, there may be severe erosions and deformities of one compartment with almost no grossly appreciated abnormalities in other compartments
Marrow between intertrabecular spaces is usually fatty and appears yellow grossly, but there may be variegation
Sometimes there are subarticular pseudocysts filled with glistening fibrous tissue or even degenerative cysts, which appear spherical and hollow
If cysts are large, there may be overlying collapse of articular bone plateCollapse of articular plate and microfractures may lead to territorial secondary osteonecrosis, which may be seen grossly
sub_points: Collapse of articular plate and microfractures may lead to territorial secondary osteonecrosis, which may be seen grossly

General Features.text: Osteophytes, which are outgrowths of new bone with variable amounts of overlying fibrocartilage or hyaline cartilage, are seen grossly at periphery of joint and sometimes on altered joint surfaces
These often contain hematopoietic bone marrow, and their marrow is redder than that of remaining medullary cavities
It is thought that osteophyte formation is adaptive response to loss of joint stability that invariably accompanies loss of joint cartilage and change in shape of opposing joint surfaces
However, in osteoarthrosis, trade off for joint stability is decrease in range of joint motion, sometimes resulting in debilitating symptoms

Fragmentation of portions of articular cartilage or of osteophytes may lead to formation of intraarticular loose bodies (joint mice)Cartilage component of these loose bodies usually remains viable and, when detached from normal tissues, its chondrocytes undergo proliferation in centrifugal fashionWith progression of time, loose bodies may enlarge and cause secondary mechanical joint problems, which become worse with time
sub_points: Cartilage component of these loose bodies usually remains viable and, when detached from normal tissues, its chondrocytes undergo proliferation in centrifugal fashion
With progression of time, loose bodies may enlarge and cause secondary mechanical joint problems, which become worse with time

Histologic Features.text: Early changes include change of cartilage surface from smooth to fibrillar, with microscopic superficial fissuring of superficial cartilage
Tidemark (normally solitary blue line corresponding to zone of calcification) tends to become duplicated at fairly early stages of degenerative process

Progression of degenerative process is marked by fissures (usually vertically oriented) extending to some depth of articular cartilageAt this stage, there is active proteoglycan loss and varying amounts of cartilage thickness loss
sub_points: At this stage, there is active proteoglycan loss and varying amounts of cartilage thickness loss

Histologic Features.text: When cartilage loss is significant enough to affect stability, there is usually osteophyte formationThis usually happens prior to full-thickness erosion of cartilage, and sometimes it is dominant feature in surgical specimensOsteophytes may be peripheral or they may occur on articular surface, in which case there is vascularization of residual articular cartilage with development of secondary ossification center by process histologically akin to endochondral ossification
sub_points: This usually happens prior to full-thickness erosion of cartilage, and sometimes it is dominant feature in surgical specimens

Osteophytes may be peripheral or they may occur on articular surface, in which case there is vascularization of residual articular cartilage with development of secondary ossification center by process histologically akin to endochondral ossification

Histologic Features.text: Chondrocytes in residual articular cartilage become active, and evidence of their proliferation is seen by formation of clusters of chondrocyte clones, especially near areas of fissuring
Redistribution of forces results in changes in architecture of underlying bone, which may be derived from simple remodeling or even from healing of microtrabecular fractures
Subarticular bone plate usually becomes sclerotic in areas of full-thickness cartilage erosion, especially where there is bone on bone contact

Sclerotic subarticular plate is often site of attempted repair of articular surface from vascularized underlying boneRepair tissue usually consists of fibrous tissue or fibrocartilaginous tufts that extend to otherwise polished osseous surface and extend to underlying intertrabecular spaces
sub_points: Repair tissue usually consists of fibrous tissue or fibrocartilaginous tufts that extend to otherwise polished osseous surface and extend to underlying intertrabecular spaces

Histologic Features.text: Changes in marrow of intertrabecular spaces are variable, but there are often ischemic changes at least superficiallyThese changes may be accompanied by fibrosisIf there has been significant disruption of articular surface, there may be foci of articular detritus with varying amounts of histiocytic reaction in intertrabecular spaces
sub_points: These changes may be accompanied by fibrosis
If there has been significant disruption of articular surface, there may be foci of articular detritus with varying amounts of histiocytic reaction in intertrabecular spaces

Histologic Features.text: Fibrosis of intertrabecular spaces may be accompanied by myxoid changes with secondary encystificationSubarticular degenerative cysts may begin in this fashionAdditionally, defects in cartilage and subarticular bone plate allow ingress of synovial fluid into intertrabecular spacesPressure of this fluid is associated with resorption of peripheral osseous trabeculae, resulting in formation of spherical subarticular cysts
sub_points: Subarticular degenerative cysts may begin in this fashion
Additionally, defects in cartilage and subarticular bone plate allow ingress of synovial fluid into intertrabecular spaces
Pressure of this fluid is associated with resorption of peripheral osseous trabeculae, resulting in formation of spherical subarticular cysts

Histologic Features.text: Synovium often shows subsynovial fibrous thickening, which (depending upon type of hematoxylin used) may appear variably myxoidThis often causes its surface to appear villous, but usually without visually significant proliferation of synoviocytes (papillary hypertrophy of synovium)There is often accentuation of vasculature with synovial capillaries appearing dilated
sub_points: This often causes its surface to appear villous, but usually without visually significant proliferation of synoviocytes (papillary hypertrophy of synovium)
There is often accentuation of vasculature with synovial capillaries appearing dilated

Histologic Features.text: Synovial inflammation is variable, and there are often lymphocytic aggregates seen in perivascular locationThese characteristically do not form germinal follicles as are seen in primary synovial inflammatory disorders, and plasma cells tend to be sparse
sub_points: These characteristically do not form germinal follicles as are seen in primary synovial inflammatory disorders, and plasma cells tend to be sparse

Histologic Features.text: Degenerative changes happening in background of inflammatory/immune diseases are sometimes associated with circumscribed collections of neutrophils in subarticular intertrabecular spaces (pseudoabscesses)When such pseudoabscesses are identified, it is imperative to look carefully at sections of synovium from same patient, because these will often demonstrate lymphoplasmacytic inflammation including germinal follicles and reactive plasma cells, frequently with binucleation, often producing intracellular and extracellular immunoglobulin collections (Russell bodies)These findings should arouse suspicion of underlying rheumatoid, psoriatic, or other chronic inflammatory systemic disorderIt is very important to do this before incorporating diagnosis of infection in pathology report since infection is direct contraindication to total joint arthroplasty
sub_points: When such pseudoabscesses are identified, it is imperative to look carefully at sections of synovium from same patient, because these will often demonstrate lymphoplasmacytic inflammation including germinal follicles and reactive plasma cells, frequently with binucleation, often producing intracellular and extracellular immunoglobulin collections (Russell bodies)
These findings should arouse suspicion of underlying rheumatoid, psoriatic, or other chronic inflammatory systemic disorder
It is very important to do this before incorporating diagnosis of infection in pathology report since infection is direct contraindication to total joint arthroplasty

Histologic Features.text: Loose bodies have variable histological appearanceUsually have cartilaginous component and sometimes have osteocartilaginous componentIf loose body is derived from osteophyte, or from articular cartilage with some subarticular bone, osseous and marrow component appears necrotic histologicallyIf loose body lodges in soft tissue structure and becomes revascularized, there may be appositional new bone formation on surfaces of necrotic bone, akin to "creeping substitution" seen in osteonecrosisCartilaginous component may be fibrocartilage, hyaline cartilage, or mixture of bothProliferation of chondrocytes along with production of cartilage matrix is seen as zones of successive centrifugally arranged crowded chondrocytesIf there are many loose bodies that are small, process may be mistaken for synovial chondromatosis both grossly and histologically, but true synovial chondromatosis is not usually associated with advanced degenerative joint disease and arrangement of chondrocytes in chondromatosis tends to be clonal and micronodular in appearanceIn addition, loose bodies derived from articular cartilage tend to preserve portions of their tidemark, but no tidemark appears in chondromatosis
sub_points: Usually have cartilaginous component and sometimes have osteocartilaginous component
If loose body is derived from osteophyte, or from articular cartilage with some subarticular bone, osseous and marrow component appears necrotic histologically

If loose body lodges in soft tissue structure and becomes revascularized, there may be appositional new bone formation on surfaces of necrotic bone, akin to "creeping substitution" seen in osteonecrosis
Cartilaginous component may be fibrocartilage, hyaline cartilage, or mixture of both
Proliferation of chondrocytes along with production of cartilage matrix is seen as zones of successive centrifugally arranged crowded chondrocytes

If there are many loose bodies that are small, process may be mistaken for synovial chondromatosis both grossly and histologically, but true synovial chondromatosis is not usually associated with advanced degenerative joint disease and arrangement of chondrocytes in chondromatosis tends to be clonal and micronodular in appearanceIn addition, loose bodies derived from articular cartilage tend to preserve portions of their tidemark, but no tidemark appears in chondromatosis
In addition, loose bodies derived from articular cartilage tend to preserve portions of their tidemark, but no tidemark appears in chondromatosis

Cytologic Features.text: This usually contains joint debris, but there is relatively small number of inflammatory cells, usually 500-1,000 total leukocytes per cubic mm

Superficial Subarticular Insufficiency F.text: Almost always not identified by conventional radiography
Patients may complain of pain for several months, but usual presentation is of rather abrupt onset
If fracture is chronic, there may be element of secondary osteoarthrosis because of mechanical alterations
Patients are usually osteoporotic females or overweight middle-aged males
Process is usually detectable by MR, but MR is seldom performed in patients thought to have osteoarthrosis

Avascular Necrosis.text: Patients are often younger than those with osteoarthrosis by decades
If condition is associated with steroid therapy, collagen vascular diseases, or underlying inherited conditions (i.e., GaucherÂ disease), patients often present with bilateral disease

If condition is subacute or chronic, there is often overlay of degenerative joint disease, which is complicated by fact that primary osteoarthrosis may cause secondary trabecular microfractures, which produce varying amounts of necrotic bone
There may be no symptoms until disease is advanced and produces secondary fractures of articular plate and cartilage or collapse of joint

Neuropathic Joint (Charcot Joint).text: Breakdown of joint due to combination of proprioceptive and sensation loss with laxity and instability of supporting tissues
Joint erodes rather rapidly, so destructive part of osteoarthrosis is present, but there is very little or no bone production, so joint becomes less stable, increasing destruction secondarily
Radiographically, there is joint destruction with signs of instability and visible joint detritusVery little associated pain
sub_points: Very little associated pain

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Changes in articular cartilage varying from slight fibrillation to complete cartilage loss
Formation of osteophytes at specimen margins or on articular surfaces
Subarticular sclerosis with smooth polishing of articular surface
Ischemic marrow changes, presence of articular detritus in the marrow spaces, subarticular cyst formation, and microtrabecular fractures
Synovial hypertrophy, usually with villous formation, dominated by subsynovial fibrosis often showing prominent vasculature
Degree of inflammation is small and usually lymphocytic and perivascularGerminal follicles are not feature
sub_points: Germinal follicles are not feature

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Synovial hyperplasia is not diffuse feature, although there may be reactive focal hyperplasia
Joint detritus varies from small fragments of cartilage and bone to large, intraarticular loose bodies dominated by cartilage proliferation

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Total joint replacement specimens should have sections made not only of articular degenerative changes but of soft tissues, including synovial tissues and menisciThis will not only reveal some associations not demonstrated grossly or radiographically, like incidental chondrocalcinosis, but it may help pathologist alert surgeon to undiagnosed underlying systemic disorder, like rheumatoid arthritis or seronegative spondyloarthritisSynovial lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with proliferative synovitis may also help pathologist distinguish subarticular pseudoabscess from true unsuspected infection
sub_points: This will not only reveal some associations not demonstrated grossly or radiographically, like incidental chondrocalcinosis, but it may help pathologist alert surgeon to undiagnosed underlying systemic disorder, like rheumatoid arthritis or seronegative spondyloarthritis
Synovial lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with proliferative synovitis may also help pathologist distinguish subarticular pseudoabscess from true unsuspected infection

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Correlation of excised total joints with clinical imaging studies is important because it sometimes shows that very sensitive techniques such as MR are overly sensitive in predicting degree of cartilage loss

If there is no apparent area of cartilage loss in specimen, particularly if there are no osteophytes, diligent search should be made for small subarticular insufficiency fracture, which is cause of severe pain that may be mistaken clinically for degenerative joint disease
